Title.evidence: Randomised Controlled Trial Comparing AR-Based and Accelerometer-Based Portable Navigation Systems in THA

Participants.evidence: Patients with osteoarthritis, idiopathic osteonecrosis, rheumatoid arthritis, or femoral neck fracture scheduled for unilateral primary THA were included.

Intervention.evidence: The AR-based system was compared to the accelerometer-based system

Objective.evidence: This randomised controlled trial aimed to compare the accuracy of acetabular cup placement using an augmented reality (AR)-based portable navigation system versus an accelerometer-based system in total hip arthroplasty (THA).

Method_Outcome.evidence: primary outcome being the absolute difference in cup placement angles measured on postoperative radiographs

Randomisation_Allocation.evidence: Participants were randomised using a computer-generated sequence and allocation was concealed in opaque envelopes.

Blinding.evidence: The outcome assessors and patients were blinded.

Number_Randomised.evidence: Between August and December 2021, 126 patients were randomised (62 to AR group, 64 to accelerometer group).

Number_Analysed.evidence: 62 to AR group, 64 to accelerometer group

Result_Outcome.evidence: The mean absolute difference in radiographic anteversion angle was smaller in the AR group (2° ± 2°) compared to the accelerometer group (5° ± 4°; 95% CI -4.2° to -2.0°; p < 0.001).

Harms.evidence: Few complications were observed in either group.
